name: Cloudflare Tunnel Alerts.txt - Possible alerts
description: This section explains a specific alert that may be triggered when using Cloudflare Tunnel, which is a service that allows secure access to private resources from the public internet. The alert, named 'Load Balancing Health Alert', indicates an issue with the origin server or pool configuration, where the response code received from the origin does not match the expected response code. This alert helps identify potential problems with the load balancing setup or the origin server's health.
use_cases: Monitoring the health and availability of origin servers
Troubleshooting issues with load balancing configurations
Ensuring proper response codes from origin servers

name: Cloudflare Tunnel Alerts.txt - Alert1
description: This section explains an alert related to the failure of a health check for a Cloudflare client running on one of the clusters (cde-green). It suggests that there is another cluster handling the job, so it's not a critical issue. The section provides steps to troubleshoot the issue, such as checking the status of pods, analyzing Cloudflare Load Balancer Analytics for errors, and verifying the configuration of the 'Monitor HealthCheck' at the Cloudflare Load Balancer side.
use_cases: Monitoring the health of Cloudflare clients running on different clusters
Troubleshooting and resolving issues related to failed health checks
Analyzing Cloudflare Load Balancer Analytics for errors
Verifying and updating the configuration of 'Monitor HealthCheck' at the Cloudflare Load Balancer side

name: Cloudflare Tunnel Alerts.txt - Alert2

use_cases: Monitoring the status of tunnels and origins

Troubleshooting and resolving tunnel-related issues

name: Cloudflare Tunnel Alerts.txt - Alert3
description: This section explains an alert triggered when the number of Cloudflare Tunnel pods running in one or both of the CDE clusters falls below 2. This alert has a high severity level, indicating a potential issue with the Cloudflare Tunnel service. The description suggests that a reduced pod count could be caused by someone performing an activity that brought down the pods. The recommended action is to investigate any recent activities that might have impacted the pod count.
use_cases: Monitoring the health and availability of Cloudflare Tunnel pods
Detecting potential issues or disruptions in the Cloudflare Tunnel service
Troubleshooting and investigating the root cause of reduced pod counts

name: Cloudflare Tunnel Alerts.txt - How to Check Cloudflare Loadbalancer Analytics
description: This section provides instructions on how to access and view the load balancing analytics for a website hosted on Cloudflare. It explains that users need to log into their Cloudflare account, navigate to the specific website's domain (in this case, razorpay.com), expand the 'Traffic' section in the left sidebar, and then click on 'Load Balancing Analytics' to view the load balancing data and metrics for that website.
use_cases: Monitoring website traffic and load balancing
Analyzing website performance and identifying potential bottlenecks
Optimizing website infrastructure and resource allocation
Troubleshooting website issues related to load balancing

name: Cloudflare Tunnel Alerts.txt - Side notes
description: This section explains that certain error logs related to failed QUIC stream connections and response header writing errors can be safely ignored as they are expected behaviors. It mentions that Cloudflare's pod establishes 4 connections to the Cloudflare datacenter, and if some of these connections fail, the errors will be logged but quickly recovered. Additionally, it clarifies that the response header writing error is expected for the health check endpoint but should be investigated if seen for other endpoints.
use_cases: Understanding and triaging expected error logs in Cloudflare Tunnel
Monitoring and troubleshooting Cloudflare Tunnel connections
Configuring health checks for Cloudflare Load Balancer
